dataset.title: IWS

individualName.surName: Kendra Cheruvelil, Michigan State University, Co-Principal Investigator
Patricia Soranno, Michigan State University, Principal Investigator

abstract.para:
LAGOS-NE contains data for all 51,102 lakes and reservoirs > 4 ha in the 17 U.S. state study area and along their borders (1,800,000 sq. km.), referred to as the census lake population. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database complements three data modules called LAGOS-NE-LOCUS, LAGOS-NE-GEO, and LAGOS-NE-LIMNO. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database contains geospatial data layers describing the boundaries, spatial classifications, and freshwater features used to compile the LAGOS-NE database. The LAGOS-NE IWS layer contains interlake watershed polygons for all of the LAGOS-NE lakes greater than or equal to 4 hectares. The watershed delineations were performed with an automated process custom to LAGOS-NE and are defined as follows: The area of land that drains directly into a lake, and into all upstream-connected, permanent streams to that lake exclusive of any upstream lake watersheds for lakes ? 10 ha that are connected via permanent streams.
Note: Complete metadata is available within the download file. This metadata can be viewed with esri ArcGIS software or by viewing the imbedded .xml file. Coverages and grids contain a file called metadata.xml and shapefiles contain a file called (shapefile_name.xml). These files can be exported to FGDC and ISO metadata formats.

section.title: Use Constraints
section.para: The LAGOS-NE database should be acknowledged in products derived from these data. The citation may include the DOI of the database and/or the accompanying manuscript.

section.title: Data Credit
section.para: METHODS PUBLICATION: Soranno, Patricia A., Edward G. Bissell, Kendra S. Cheruvelil, Samuel T. Christel, Sarah M. Collins, C. Emi Fergus, Christopher T. Filstrup et al. "Building a multi-scaled geospatial temporal ecology database from disparate data sources: fostering open science and data reuse." GigaScience 4, no. 1 (2015): 28. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS: Support for creating LAGOS-NE was provided by the National Science Foundation MacroSystems Biology Program in the Emerging Frontiers Division of the Biological Sciences Directorate (EF-1065786and EF-1638679 to MSU, EF-1065649 to ISU, and EF-1065818 and EF-1638554 to UW) and the USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture, Hatch project 176820 to PAS. Author KEW thanks the STRIVE Programme (2011-W-FS-7) from the Environmental Protection Agency, Ireland. Author SMC also thanks the NSF Division of Biological Infrastructure (1401954). Further credits for other modules LAGOS-NE beyond the GIS Database are detailed in Soranno et al. 2017.

purpose.para: We have created a database for lakes in the northeastern-most 17 U.S. states called LAGOS-NE (LAke multi-scaled GeOSpatial and temporal database). We had three related motivations for developing this database: (1) to develop the basic understanding of lake nutrients and productivity at sub-continental scales, with a focus on studying cross-scale interactions and their drivers using water quality data on thousands of lakes collected overacross the last several decades (see Soranno et al. 2014 and Soranno et al. 2015 for details); (2) to build the capacity to apply this scientific understanding to environmental management and policy of freshwaters; and, (3) to foster broad-scale research by designing an open-science database infrastructure that includes detailed characterization of lake ecological context that is extensible for future uses and by making the data and methods publicly accessible. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database is provided for the purposes of displaying LAGOS-NE data, understanding their geospatial relationships, and supporting further spatial analyses with these data. The LAGOS-NE IWS layer identifies watersheds for the purpose of studying the influence of ecological context on lake nutrients and water quality.

publisher.organizationName: Patricia Soranno, Michigan State University, Principal Investigator

dataset.pubPlace: 334 Natural Resources Bldg., 480 Wilson Rd., East Lansing, MI, 48824

spatialVector.entityDescription: LAGOS-NE contains data for all 51,102 lakes and reservoirs > 4 ha in the 17 U.S. state study area and along their borders (1,800,000 sq. km.), referred to as the census lake population. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database complements three data modules called LAGOS-NE-LOCUS, LAGOS-NE-GEO, and LAGOS-NE-LIMNO. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database contains geospatial data layers describing the boundaries, spatial classifications, and freshwater features used to compile the LAGOS-NE database. The LAGOS-NE IWS layer contains interlake watershed polygons for all of the LAGOS-NE lakes greater than or equal to 4 hectares. The watershed delineations were performed with an automated process custom to LAGOS-NE and are defined as follows: The area of land that drains directly into a lake, and into all upstream-connected, permanent streams to that lake exclusive of any upstream lake watersheds for lakes ? 10 ha that are connected via permanent streams.

externallyDefinedFormat.formatName: zip file with ARC/INFO shape file

description.para: The complete documentation of the process is found in Soranno et al. (2015), Supplemental File 8, located at http://dx.doi.org/10.1186/s13742-015-0067-4. The major steps in the watershed delineation process are as follows: 1) Obtain and mosaic NED DEMs, NHD data. Introduce 'walls' that prevent flow from crossing HU8 boundaries. Data is projected here to USGS Albers coordinate system, and later as necessary. 2) DEM conditioning: Burn NHD flowlines (streams, and more*) into DEM using AGREE-like conditioning. This step ensures that flow accumulates into cells that correspond with the NHD flowlines. 3) DEM conditioning: Fill pits in the DEM. This step prevents flow from accumulating in isolated pits (Jenson and Domingue 1988). 4) Force the flow to not cross HU8 boundaries by adding 'walls' along the boundary. 5) Calculate D8 flow direction from the DEM. 6) Select pour points: All NHD flowlines and lakes meeting the size threshold and being of certain FCodes (non-intermittent lakes and reservoirs) are included. Lakes take precedence where lakes and flowlines (in particular, artificial paths through lakes) overlap. 7) Calculate watersheds from the flow direction rasters using the selected pour points. 8) Remove watersheds smaller than 1ha and those that do not intersect the NHD flowlines or selected lakes. Use a 'nibble' algorithm to partition the areas where watersheds were removed into the retained watersheds. 9) Ensure that watershed polygons do not cross HU8 boundaries and that the lakes are perfectly nested within their own watersheds. 10) Aggregate watersheds. An aggregated watershed is created for each eligible lake in the NHD. The lake itself is erased from the watershed polygon and any remaining holes smaller than 3.9 ha are filled in. a. 'Interlake watersheds': All of the watersheds corresponding to network elements (lakes/streams) upstream of any eligible lake are merged until a 10-hectare lake is reached in the network, and no watersheds including and beyond the 10-hectare lake are included. b. 'Cumulative watersheds': All watersheds corresponding to network elements (lakes/streams) upstream of any eligible lake are merged until the HU8 boundary prevents any additional watersheds from being included. The lake itself is erased from the watershed polygon and any remaining holes smaller than 3.9 ha are filled in.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The area of the interlake watershed, in hectares.
The Permanent Identifier of the lake with which the interlake watershed is associated.

textDomain.definition: 40-character GUID value locally assigned during data creation or 9-digit string inherited from original ComID

attribute.attributeDefinition: The percent area of the polygon for which complete NWI coverage was obtained for analysis in LAGOS-NE.
Area of the polygon, in hectares, that is with the United States.

textDomain.definition: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The perimeter of the interlake watershed, in kilometers.
The longitude of the centroid of the polygon (NAD83).
The area of the lake itself, in hectares.
Area of the polygon, in hectares, where complete NWI data coverage was obtained for analysis in LAGOS-NE.
The latitude of the centroid of the polygon (NAD83).
A unique identifier in LAGOS-NE for the regional spatial classifications (hydrologic units, political regions, or ecological drainage units).

textDomain.definition: Character string contains spatial classification prefix followed by sequentially generated numeric value

attribute.attributeDefinition: The percent area of the polygon in the USA.
Unique identifier for a lake in the LAGOS-NE database.

horizCoordSysDef.name: USA Contiguous Albers Equal Area Conic USGS version

parameter.name: Standard Parallel
parameter.description: Line of constant latitude at which the Earth and the plane intersect

parameter.name: Longitude at central meridian
parameter.description: The line of logitude at the center of the map projection

parameter.name: Latitude of projection origin
parameter.description: The latitude chosen as center of the projection

parameter.name: False Easting
parameter.description: A value added in a rectangular coordinate system, usually used to avoid negative values

parameter.name: False Northing
parameter.description: A value added in a rectangular coordinate system, usually used to avoid negative values
